c537d80ed0a.description: Media, Tech, Business Models viewed from Palo Alto and Paris
c537d80ed0a.name: Monday Note
c537d80ed0a.shortDescription: Media, Tech, Business Models viewed from Palo Alto and…

paragraphs.text: Nick Hayek’s father triumphed against Japanese quartz watch makers by playing on his own turf. Trying to defeat the established smartwatch players by playing their game won’t work. Is there something in Swatch Group’s culture that predisposes it to be competitive with Google and Apple software engineers?

Apple still refuses to release Watch numbers, but the device is estimated to have had a successful Holidays quarter. The Canalys research firm (all caveats hereby stipulated) pegs unit sales at 6M for the quarter with a revenue of $2.6B — that’s 80% of the total smartwatch market. Apple CEO Tim Cook, known for the reliability of his public statements, calls sales growth “off the charts”. If the numbers are accurate, Apple has become the second largest watchmaker by revenue, right behind Rolex.

398ed18c284.title: Or Swatch factories could produce iOS smartwatches after Apple buys the wiss company…

paragraphs.text: Or Swatch factories could produce iOS smartwatches after Apple buys the wiss company…
paragraphs.name: 3ab8

c63a57ba3a8b.title: You probably meant “analog” digital watches (SWATCH) versus “digital” digital watches.

paragraphs.text: You probably meant “analog” digital watches (SWATCH) versus “digital” digital watches. SWATCH in the beginning was a pure quartz analog watch. Anyway. If you’re right — no updates, one OS to rule them all “forever”, SWATCH is indeed doomed. They don’t have the know-how and the money to do it from scratch up. And 2018 (it will be 2019 or 2020, as we…

f9b5d4a4b6e3.title: I disagree — depending on what is behind the announcement, this could actually be a very good…

paragraphs.text: I disagree — depending on what is behind the announcement, this could actually be a very good defensive move for traditional mechanical watches. They didn’t say they were announcing a watch as such, but an ecosystem of connected things. Depending on what they actually release, this could work out.
Longer version: http://findthethread.postach.io/post/smart-swatch
paragraphs.name: 01e0

paragraphs.text:
Couldn’t agree more. First said Apple’s initiative was not serious and now, tries to communicate 18 months in advance on a market that changes really fast. 
This makes no sense. If he had a bright idea or a great project, he should develop it in silence and stun the whole world when ready. Communicating right now will just keep competition working…
paragraphs.name: 27b1

3086607e198d.title: Not every company wants to be at the mercy of some tech giant. Autonomy is a virtue.

paragraphs.text: Not every company wants to be at the mercy of some tech giant. Autonomy is a virtue.
paragraphs.name: ac05

paragraphs.text: Building a watch OS is not risk free, but it is far from impossible, and it’s the only way Swatch can keep it’s strong independent position. And gain, not lose, leadership.
paragraphs.name: b057

virtuals.subtitle: Building a watch OS is not risk free, but it is far from impossible, and it’s the only way Swatch can keep it’s strong independent position…

content.subtitle: Building a watch OS is not risk free, but it is far from impossible, and it’s the only way Swatch can keep it’s strong independent position…

d878b556168d.title: They’ll probably go for the minimum viable product: have a built-in watch face that can also…

paragraphs.text: They’ll probably go for the minimum viable product: have a built-in watch face that can also display text and/or bitmaps sent over bluetooth, and can send accelerometer data and button presses to the phone. So maybe there won’t be a need for updates, as long as the feature set is light, there aren’t any bugs and the bluetooth protocol doesn’t change…
paragraphs.name: 7d4f

virtuals.subtitle: But they should’ve rather bought Pebble before Fitbit did. At least the whole ecosystem was already set up and had ardent followers; they…

content.subtitle: But they should’ve rather bought Pebble before Fitbit did. At least the whole ecosystem was already set up and had ardent followers; they…

4660b490abfa.title: I think the Swatch Group understands that there is still a big gap in the emerging Smartwatches…

paragraphs.text: I think the Swatch Group understands that there is still a big gap in the emerging Smartwatches category that co-relates perfectly with how Swatch originally positioned itself when faced with Japanese Quartz watches — At the bottom of the pyramid.
paragraphs.name: d20a

virtuals.subtitle: There exists a vast market for quality, affordable smartwatches based on a combination of LE chipsets & an OS that focus on what should be…

content.subtitle: There exists a vast market for quality, affordable smartwatches based on a combination of LE chipsets & an OS that focus on what should be…

48bd4f93845.title: I’m surprised not to see the word “platform” here.

paragraphs.text: I’m surprised not to see the word “platform” here.
Whatever the OS’s qualities, if the Swatch (Tissot?) is to interface well to the IoT, it will need to either dictate or play friendly with dozens of other companies’ products.
paragraphs.name: 67d2

fee1945cf3e9.title: Very complex, and interesting question… Ultimately, what matters is that there is no place for more…

paragraphs.text: Very complex, and interesting question… Ultimately, what matters is that there is no place for more than two dominant OS (irrespective on how good/bad they can be …), because developers cannot bear the cost of multiple ports. In the case of the watch, there is indeed a notion of an ecosystem, with third party apps, but it can be argued that the…
paragraphs.name: 1b9e

virtuals.subtitle: And by the way, the same question could be raised for cars, with several more orders of magnitude ….

content.subtitle: And by the way, the same question could be raised for cars, with several more orders of magnitude ….

e815f7795374.title: Although I do think your conclusions are — unfortunately, right, I’m afraid they are based on…

paragraphs.text: Although I do think your conclusions are — unfortunately, right, I’m afraid they are based on incorrect facts. Hayek father pulled it by challenging the Japanese on their own turf with a quartz watch, using innovative engineering (making possible cheap production in Switzerland) and marketing skills to outsmart them. Sort of “à la Jobs”.
paragraphs.name: 1b34

57eac33a7ffe.title: I don’t think there is an “if” because that would imply Apple deliberately lied to everyone and…

paragraphs.text: I don’t think there is an “if” because that would imply Apple deliberately lied to everyone and more so, if inaccurate, every other watch maker would have called them out on it.
paragraphs.name: 7e15

1c8cd015c51d.title: Apple is about the ecosystem where every Apple device is connected, I love my Apple Watch series 2.

paragraphs.text: Apple is about the ecosystem where every Apple device is connected, I love my Apple Watch series 2.

paragraphs.text: Is it ugly? no, kind of wonder which one is beautiful perhaps those with high price tags are. Beauty is in the sight of the beholder.

207fdbb1fc54.title: Make or buy, that is the question.

paragraphs.text: Make or buy, that is the question.

No parallel with tizenOS? PalmOS? Even chromeOS? And last but not least, even the software behemoth Microsoft didn’t succeed in the embedded OS (look at windows mobile market share). Operating Systems are a special type of engineering; once could compare it with aeronautics industry…

9367432e5d59.title: The Swatch (1983) was not a mechanical watch but a quartz, battery powered one.

paragraphs.text: The Swatch (1983) was not a mechanical watch but a quartz, battery powered one. Only the recent (2014) Sistem51 is mechanical.

paragraphs.text: Fascinating to see Swatch double-down on the follies of Nokia and perhaps also Blackberry.

paragraphs.text: Please, go on swatch.com, order a Swatch Bellamy, use it for a few weeks then let’s have this discussion again*. I bet you will see why Hayek’s vision makes perfect sense in our society:
paragraphs.name: 5f32

paragraphs.text: no constant user tracking
paragraphs.name: fbf6

paragraphs.text: no data leakage
paragraphs.name: 63ab

paragraphs.text: no privacy invasion
paragraphs.name: dae3

91ab74e5bd9b.title: Except Android is heavy which is everything Swatch is not.

paragraphs.text: Swatch could use its native — but circumscribed — cultural and technical skills to create beautiful, fun smartwatches…that run on Google’s software.
paragraphs.name: 5c9b

paragraphs.text: Except Android is heavy which is everything Swatch is not. Android software requires a fast CPU and lots of RAM which then requires a bigger (and heavier) battery.
paragraphs.name: a3d0

virtuals.subtitle: Just look at every Android smartwatch out there and the biggest complaint is it’s size and little battery life.

content.subtitle: Just look at every Android smartwatch out there and the biggest complaint is it’s size and little battery life.

e60ac774dd1f.title: I also have my doubts about this but I’d also rather have a nice mechanical watch with sensors, low…

paragraphs.text: I also have my doubts about this but I’d also rather have a nice mechanical watch with sensors, low energy consumption, no UI and that works well with any phone than something like an Apple Watch (which I tried and found not practical in addition to being ugly). I don’t know what Swatch’s plans are but I hope it would be something like this.
paragraphs.name: d12c

f99da2026a6d.title: I have a smartwatch which works very well, lasts one full week on a charge, with useful fitness and…

paragraphs.text: I have a smartwatch which works very well, lasts one full week on a charge, with useful fitness and notification stuff. It’s cheaper than Apple and Android Wear watches. It’s a Garmin.
paragraphs.name: 38b4
